content.description:
Whats not to like about this route. Awesome holds, cool movement and a juggy topout. Sit start on a good sidepull about 5 feet right of the tree and work your way up on good flakes. Getting your body position right and finding where the good holds are is key to sending this climb. 

  A great line on an amazing boulder.
content.protection: Landing is fairly flat. 2 pads and a spotter.
content.location: This climbs the left side on the big face of Mammoth Rock

content.description:
Sit start on two opposing undercling sidepulls. Pull on with some smears and move up to a good sidepull out left from here crossover and continue climbing up and slightly left while holding a vast amount of tension another big move or two will get you to the juggy arete, and then a balancy rockover onto the slab finishes the problem. 

 This problem has some great movement on unique rock and some great incut holds.
content.protection: 3 pads and a spotter. This face feels exposed,  but the landing is relatively flat. (At least for about 6 feet before it angles into a downhill slope.)
content.location: This problem is located on the downhill side of this large boulder,Â and is an extension into "Timeline". The starting sidepulls are located directly beneath where the name "John Clough" is chiselled into the boulder.

content.description: Sit or squat start on two sloping crimps and make a couple of hard, slightly shouldery moves out right to some incut crimps. From here a few more burly and fingery moves gets you into the stand start. From the incut jug move up into the undercling then continue up to a sloper crystal and a pair of gastons before a committing last move and fun top out. Awesome movement on some good rock!
content.protection: At least 4 pads. It gets slightly airy up there.
content.location: This is the downhill face of the boulder. It is also the tallest face of the boulder. This problem starts slightly right of the center.

content.description: A stellar line on an amazing boulder! Start matched on the good incut flake and work your way into a good right hand undercling. Use your biceps and pull up into a left hand sloper sidepull. Shift your body weight around and lunge up to a thin seam. Get it good and make a desperate move up and left to a good hold. Keep it together and work your way toward the arete on good holds. Swing around the corner and celebrate.
content.location: This route climbs the right side of Mammoth rock.

content.description: The hardest line on the tall face of Mammoth Rock. This line starts in the middle of the wall. Left of "State of Fear" and right of "Timeline". Pull onto the great rock using small incut crimps, and make hard moves to blind holds in the smooth granite flake systems on the wall. This line is a direct and topout at the apex of the boulder about 25 feet off the deck. An early exit may be possible.
content.protection: Minimum of 6 pads if going for the first ascent. 10 would be better. Bring your friends and a change of underwear.
content.location: Follow the buoys into the woods. Turn right and walk for five minutes. This is the largest boulder in the park (Until you find the "Colossus" way beyond the South End). The slabs are covered in moss. This is the most natural line on the rock and it is clean.

content.description: Stand start with the left hand on a small crystal sidepull at about head height, and a good right hand undercling sidepull at waist height. Or use two undercling. Pull on with good feet and make a toss for the slopey lip. Get both hands up there and throw up a heel or toe and mantel it.
content.protection: Two crash pads and a spotter.
content.location: This is one of the only problems that might go on the 45 degree wall on Mammoth Rock. This line is located on the rightside of the overhang. The lefthand starting hold is located in a small seam.If the crystal rips off, this problem will not be climbable.

content.description:
Sit start at the bottom of the arete with a low left foot and hands on arete. Continue left on smooth rock with great handholds, and heelhook/smear for feet. Grab the left sidepull, work your hands up to the shark tooth, and mantle over. 

  If you want, you could go up the 5.4 slab to the top of mammoth rock.
content.location: On the right backside of Mammoth rock. The obvious line going left up the arete to the shark tooth.

content.description: Sit start with both hands on the arete. Start with the right hand on a low pocket-like hold, and the left hand slightly higher on a textured seam-pinch. Pull-on and make a few burly and shouldery moves out left on good feet before resorted to a series of strenuous right heelhooking while on some bad slopers. Smack out to a crystal hold and make a big lock-off for a mega bucket way up high and press it out. This climb tops out on the large bulging feature protruding from the lip of the block.
content.protection: 4 or 5 pads and a spotter or two. The finish is fairly high and there is a lot of lateral distance covered.
content.location: This boulder problem is found on the side of Mammoth Rock which is farthest from the Gazebo.

content.description: This is the largest and most proud boulder in the park! This boulder has a short and easy approach and is home to a few 3-4 star lines! This large block also has the potential for a few more hard boulder problems. Two of the best lines include "Timeline" and "State of Fear".
